"From the Specify Setup Mode tab, select the default startup mode of this extension, specify the user
preferences, and choose Next.

  • Default Startup Mode: The default startup mode determines how the extension is launched for all users
    that are connected to the company.
  • Automatic - SAP Business One starts the extension automatically. Users can stop automatically
    started add-ons with no impact on SAP Business One. A warning message informs users when the
    extension stops.
  • Manual - SAP Business One does not start the extension automatically. Users can start the extension
    at any time. A message informs users when a manually started extension is stopped.
  • Mandatory - SAP Business One starts the extension automatically. The extension is necessary for the
    successful operation of the SAP Business One application. The application launches the extension at
    start-up and shuts it down if the extension is terminated for any reason. Users cannot start or stop
    mandatory extensions.
  • Disabled - The extension is disabled.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA does not support automatic split purchase order by WBS code / storage location
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

We are currently working with SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud 2023  in a company that operates under a centralized purchasing model.

In SAP Business One, when creating a Purchase Order, if the items belong to different warehouses, the system automatically splits the PO into multiple purchase orders (one per warehouse). This is very useful for companies with centralized procurement but distributed warehouses/divisions, as it simplifies receiving and accounting at the warehouse level.

In SAP S/4HANA, I have observed that this functionality is not available by default. Instead, the system allows one PO to contain items for multiple plants/warehouses, and the logistics are handled separately.

üëâ My questions are:

  1. Is there a standard option/configuration in S/4HANA to achieve automatic PO split by warehouse/plant (similar to SAP Business One)?

  2. If not standard, what is the recommended best practice for centralized purchasing with bulk discounts and later distribution to different warehouses/divisions?

  3. Is the solution to use Stock Transport Orders (STO) or Central Procurement Hub after creating one bulk PO at the head office?

  4. Has anyone implemented a custom BAdI enhancement (e.g., ME_PROCESS_PO_CUST) to mimic this B1 functionality in S/4HANA?

This is a critical requirement for us since our business negotiates bulk discounts with suppliers and then distributes materials to multiple warehouses.

Any guidance, best practices, or experience sharing will be highly appreciated.

Thanks & Regards,

silambarasan RS

entry.title: Taking and storing snapshots within Datasphere itself
entry.content:
Is there a way to take and store a snapshot of a view within Datasphere?

We have a remote source system upon which we cannot implement real-time replication. We therefore have a schedule to refresh the data periodically.

We then have a series of complex SQL views built on top that produce the models.

We have a requirement to provide a snapshot of the data at 6am each day, which can then be compared to the "live" version on-demand, within the same SAC dashboard.

Is there a way to create an extract from the fact view and store it in a local table based on a task, or another suitable option?
I have searched and came across the following passing comment on learning.sap.com:
"Views transform the data at the moment they are read without storing the result (although storing the view result as a snapshot is possible)", but it doesn't explain how.

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA does not support automatic split purchase...

This behavior is by design, as S/4HANA assumes centralized PO management with decentralized logistics handled via delivery and goods receipt processes. If this auto-split is critical for your operations, explore custom enhancement via BAdI ME_PROCESS_PO_CUST

entry.title: SAP PO GraphQL Integration with XSLT Mapping
entry.content:
Introduction:

In most SAP projects, integrations are built using REST or OData. But in some cases, modern systems require GraphQL (Graph Query Language), a query language and runtime for APIs that allows clients to request exactly the data they need. When calling a GraphQL service from SAP PO, the service expects application/json, which means we need a transformation step. Using XSLT mapping, we converted the XML request into the JSON format GraphQL understands and executed the call successfully. In this post, I‚Äôll walk you through how we set this up and what we learned along the way.

Note: In this scenario, no authentication was required since the GraphQL service was internal and not exposed externally. However, if the service had been publicly accessible, common security mechanisms such as OAuth 2.0, JWT tokens, or API Keys would typically be implemented. On the SAP PO side, this would be handled by configuring the HTTP/REST adapter to pass the necessary headers (e.g., Authorization: Bearer <token>), ensuring secure communication.

 

Scenario:

Request Example:

Response Example:

 

Step 1: Create Data Type, Message Type , Service Interfaces

Data Type Request:

For this scenario, I defined a dummy field named query. The GraphQL request is embedded into this field and then passed to the target service.

Data Type Response:

You can either create the response message as a Data Type (DT) or convert it into an XSD and import it into PO as an External Definition. I converted it into an XSD and imported it into PO as an External Definition.

Message Type Request :

 

Service Interfaces: 

We also create our Service Interfaces ‚Äî one inbound and one outbound ‚Äî and, as usual, place our request and response messages accordingly.

 

 

Step 2: XSLT Mapping 

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<xsl:stylesheet version="1.0" xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform">

  <xsl:output method="text" encoding="UTF-8"/>

  <xsl:template match="/">

  <xsl:variable name="q1" select="string(/*/*[local-name()='query'])"/>

    <xsl:variable name="q">

      <xsl:choose>

        <xsl:when test="string-length($q1) > 0">

          <xsl:value-of select="$q1"/>

        </xsl:when>

        <xsl:otherwise>

          <xsl:value-of select="string(/*)"/>

        </xsl:otherwise>

      </xsl:choose>

    </xsl:variable>

    <xsl:text>{ "query":"</xsl:text>

    <xsl:call-template name="escape-json">

      <xsl:with-param name="s" select="string($q)"/>

    </xsl:call-template>

    <xsl:text>" }</xsl:text>

  </xsl:template>

  <!-- JSON escape: \  "  LF  CR  TAB -->

  <xsl:template name="escape-json">

    <xsl:param name="s"/>

    <!-- \ -> \\ -->

    <xsl:variable name="step1">

      <xsl:call-template name="replace">

        <xsl:with-param name="text" select="$s"/>

        <xsl:with-param name="search" select="'\'"/>

        <xsl:with-param name="repl" select="'\\'"/>

      </xsl:call-template>

    </xsl:variable>

    <!-- " -> \" (XML i√ßin " kullan) -->

    <xsl:variable name="step2">

      <xsl:call-template name="replace">

        <xsl:with-param name="text"   select="string($step1)"/>

        <xsl:with-param name="search" select="'"'"/>

        <xsl:with-param name="repl"   select="'\"'"/>

      </xsl:call-template>

    </xsl:variable>

    <!-- LF, CR, TAB -->

    <xsl:variable name="step3">

      <xsl:call-template name="replace">

        <xsl:with-param name="text" select="string($step2)"/>

        <xsl:with-param name="search" select="'
'"/>

        <xsl:with-param name="repl" select="'\n'"/>

      </xsl:call-template>

    </xsl:variable>

    <xsl:variable name="step4">

      <xsl:call-template name="replace">

        <xsl:with-param name="text" select="string($step3)"/>

        <xsl:with-param name="search" select="''"/>

        <xsl:with-param name="repl" select="'\r'"/>

      </xsl:call-template>

    </xsl:variable>

    <xsl:variable name="step5">

      <xsl:call-template name="replace">

        <xsl:with-param name="text" select="string($step4)"/>

        <xsl:with-param name="search" select="'	'"/>

        <xsl:with-param name="repl" select="'\t'"/>

      </xsl:call-template>

    </xsl:variable>

    <xsl:value-of select="string($step5)"/>

  </xsl:template>

  <!-- basic replace -->

  <xsl:template name="replace">

    <xsl:param name="text"/><xsl:param name="search"/><xsl:param name="repl"/>

    <xsl:choose>

      <xsl:when test="contains($text, $search)">

        <xsl:value-of select="substring-before($text, $search)"/>

        <xsl:value-of select="$repl"/>

        <xsl:call-template name="replace">

          <xsl:with-param name="text" select="substring-after($text, $search)"/>

          <xsl:with-param name="search" select="$search"/>

          <xsl:with-param name="repl" select="$repl"/>

        </xsl:call-template>

      </xsl:when>

      <xsl:otherwise>

        <xsl:value-of select="$text"/>

      </xsl:otherwise>

    </xsl:choose>

  </xsl:template>

</xsl:stylesheet>

 

The purpose of this XSLT mapping is to transform the XML structure coming from SAP into the JSON format required by the GraphQL service. More specifically, it extracts the GraphQL query string from the XML payload and embeds it into the query field of the JSON request body. Without this step, the GraphQL service would not accept the request, since it only supports application/json.

We import the XSLT mapping into PO as an imported archive.

 

 

Step 3 : Message Mappings

If there is no need for a custom graphical mapping, we perform a one-to-one mapping.

 

 

Step 4: Operation Mapping & Test

In the Operation Mapping, we place our one-to-one mapping as the first step, and then add a second step for the XSLT mapping.

We have successfully tested our XSLT mapping. For guidance on sending GraphQL requests with an application/json body, you can refer to the official GraphQL documentation or your server‚Äôs implementation guide;

https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/graphql/graphql-http/ 

Test XML : 

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<ns0:MT_getFlightLegList_Req xmlns:ns0=********************************>

     <query>

<![CDATA[

Your GraphQL Request

  ]]>

</query>

</ns0:MT_getFlightLegList_Req>

 

 

Step 5: Integrated Configuration

Since PO does not have a GraphQL adapter, we will use REST. We create a standard REST Receiver adapter, and because the call from SAP will come via proxy, our sender is the SOAP XI adapter.

Rest Receiver Data Format Step:

Remember that we‚Äôve converted the payload into the JSON format accepted by the service using XSLT. In other words, our adapter will receive a structure in JSON format.

We create the standard Integrated Configuration (ICO) and activate the scenario.

 

 

Step 6: Testing

You can use Send Message to test.

 

Monitoring:

Request BI Step:

After Mapping Step:

 

Response :

As the response includes personal data, I cannot share it. Nevertheless, this confirms that the request was successfully executed and a response was returned.

 

NOTE: There are scenarios where combining a Message Type with an External Definition in the same Service Interface prevents ABAP proxy generation in SAP. To mitigate this risk, ensure consistency by using the same artifact type (either Message Type or External Definition) on both request and response.

 

Thank you,

Deniz Z.

entry.title: Re: ATC Cloud readiness
entry.content:
Hi @ShiveshS 

Thank you for your question. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the Cloudification Repository is the only officially supported source for ATC checks. The system validates the URL, which is why custom SICF services are not permitted. This is also why you received the error when trying to replace the JSON with your own filtered service.

Currently, the CR JSON always delivers the full set of checks. There is no supported way to directly reduce or filter the JSON at source. Instead, the recommended approach is to use the ATC check variant configuration in Eclipse/ADT to control which object categories are checked. This way, you can keep the official repository intact but restrict the checks to only what is relevant to you for example deprecated tables.

I suggest you consider the following recommended Steps:

  • Use the official Cloudification Repository link as delivered by SAP and do not replace it with custom SICF services.
  • Create or adapt a custom ATC check variant in Eclipse/ADT.
  • Within the variant, deactivate the categories you do not need (e.g., BAPIs, FMs) and keep only those relevant for deprecated tables.
  • Run the ATC with your custom variant to focus results specifically on deprecated table usage.

This ensures your checks stay compliant with clean-core extensibility principles while allowing you to narrow the scope to your project‚Äôs needs.

For more details, consult the following references:

Cloudification Repository

SAP/abap-atc-cr-cv-s4hc

I hope this provides the desired insights. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Storage location not found for profile R61I error whe...
entry.content:
Hello @ayechan 

The error you mentioned usually means that the storage location determination for the POS profile is not maintained in configuration. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, POS inbound postings require a mapping between POS Profile (R61I in your case), Plant and Storage Location

This happens because, when the system tries to post goods movements from the inbound POS data, it looks up the storage location via the POS profile customizing. If the storage location is missing or not mapped, the system cannot determine where to post the stock.

How to fix it in Public Cloud

  1. Go to Manage Your Solution (SSCUI) ‚Üí Define Store Profiles and Assign Storage Location.
    • SSCUI ID: 103186, define Store Profile and Assign Storage Location.
  2. Check whether profile R61I has an entry with the correct Plant and Storage Location.
  3. If not, add the assignment so that the POS inbound service can find the storage location.
  4. Thereafter re-run your POS inbound job.

To summarise, the error occurs because the POS profile R61I does not have a storage location assigned in the configuration. Once you maintain the correct plant/storage location mapping for this POS profile in SSCUI 103186, the inbound service will process successfully.

For further details please consult  the references below.

Integration of POS Sales Data with S/4HANA Cloud

API Hub: POS Sales Transactions Create (SAP_COM_0109)

I hope this provides the desired insights. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: BAS on premise deployment errors for recently created...
entry.content:
We run into the same issue and as explained already, an option is to set back the _version to 1.17.0 

The error is not occuring before, because it comes from a change how the manifest.json is created during build process in the dist folder. With the latest versions of the ui5 cli or ux toolings, the single string entry of the i18n property is converted in the dist folder from for example  "i18n": "i18n/i18n.properties" to 

"i18n": {
      "bundleUrl": "i18n/i18n.properties",
      "supportedLocales": [
        "en",
        "de",
        "fr"
      ],
      "fallbackLocale": "en"
    }

And if your system is still an R3 with SAPUI5 Version 1.71 this runs into an error, as this fallback handling is only available in 1.77 and higher. We ran into this trap also today and thanks to the initial answers of a possible solution. After our deployment worked I then investigated a bit further to identify the root cause of this error.

entry.title: Re: App Fiori Maintenance Scheduling Board add custom lab...
entry.content:
Hi @DavidLorente 

Thank you for your question.

In the Maintenance Scheduling Board (Gantt Chart) in S/4HANA Public Cloud, the label options you see are fixed to standard fields provided by SAP. Currently, there is no configuration option to add additional custom labels directly to this dropdown list without a custom development.

Here are some options you should consider:

  1. You can add custom fields to maintenance orders or operations. These fields will be visible in the object itself and can be used in reporting. However, CFL does not extend the label list in the Gantt chart by default.
  2. If your requirement is analytical (for display/reporting purposes), you could expose the custom field via CDS view and use it in Fiori analytical apps. But again, this does not extend the label dropdown in the scheduling board.
  3. For UI adaptations, you can check if the Maintenance Scheduling Board allows extensibility (via Adapt UI or UI Flexibility). As of now, SAP restricts such extensions for Gantt charts in Public Cloud, so adding a new label option is not supported.
  4. Since this is a limitation, the only long-term option (without custom development) is to submit it as an influence request to SAP. SAP periodically extends fields available in such dropdowns based on customer feedback.

To summarise, out-of-the-box, you cannot add new labels to the Gantt chart in S/4HANA Public Cloud. Custom fields can be added to orders but won‚Äôt appear in the label dropdown. For now, the only path is either SAP influence request or custom extension (if SAP later releases extensibility for this UI).

I hope this provides the desired insights. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Can you tell me what authoirzation is missing for this SU53 screenshot
Re: Filter for last event of any case with Signavio Proce...
entry.content:
Hi Benedict, thanks for the question! 

What you are trying to achieve makes total sense, but unfortunately is not yet supported trivially inside of advanced filters. I imagine the error you are receiving is something like "multiple levels of nesting is not supported"? This is because the Event Level filter is already operating on the nested events themselves (not flattened), which restricts it from being able to access to the aggregated information over all events. In short, the event filter can only access attributes associated with the event directly, not aggregates that are calculated over all events.

As a short-term work around, the advice I would give would be to create an case-level attribute inside of your SQL script with the timestamp of the last event per case, re-run the pipeline, and then leverage that case-level attribute inside of an event-level advanced filter. E.g. "case_level_last_end_time_attribute" = "end_time".  

In the coming weeks we will be releasing a new capability that will allow you to create this very case-level attribute with SIGNAL inside the analysis layer directly, which will then also be able to be used as input for the advanced filter. This feature is called "Calculated Attributes", and should support this use case perfectly, as it would calculate the Last event per case in a separate level of query execution, allowing it to be used as input to your advanced filter. If you are interested, we might be able to grant you and your organization early access. Please let us know in this thread üôÇ 

Until then, thanks a lot for your question, and sorry that no simply solution is available for you to use. If you have any follow up questions or something is unclear, please don't hesitate to ask!

entry.title: Re: Activating Business Function JFMIP_MM_01 and Switch M...
entry.content:
activating the Business Function JFMIP_MM_01 (via its corresponding switch MRM_SFWS_JFMIP_01) is irreversible. This is because it fundamentally changes the data model and business process for GR/IR account clearing, moving from the classic "value-based" approach to a "quantity-based" approach required by the Fiori app.

The primary "problem" is not an error, but a fundamental and permanent change in your business process and how you handle GR/IR accounts

entry.title: Re: Comlemento de Pago de Factoraje con DRC?
entry.content:
Hello @MartinRodriguezG 

Yes, your need can be fulfilled in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud edition through the Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) eDocument solution.

The standard DRC framework for Mexico's Complemento de Pago (Comprobante de Recepci√≥n de Pagos or CRP) is intended to accommodate this situation. To add a second payment node in the XML for factoring, you should utilise the extensibility features of the eDocument framework.

How to Set Up the Second Payment Node

Standard Configuration: The default setup in DRC addresses the basic payment complement. For factoring scenarios, where a payment comes from a factor (a different payer than the original customer), this functionality needs to be extended.

Utilise the eDoc_Adaptor BAdI: This Business Add-In (BAdI) is essential for expanding eDocument capabilities. You can add custom logic within this BAdI to.

    • Identify factoring scenarios based on your business rules, for example, a specific clearing account, bank key, or a custom field on the payment document.
    • Obtain the required details for the second payment node from the financial document or a comprehensive data source.
    • Dynamically generate the second <Pago> node in the XML payload, filling it with the details of the factoring payment.

Extensible Fields: The eDocument framework in the public cloud supports extensions via custom fields and APIs. You can add custom fields to the payment document to include specific information needed for the second payment node, which your BAdI implementation can then access.

This method is fully compatible with SAP S/4HANA Cloud and adheres to the Clean Core strategy by utilising the available extensibility framework instead of altering the standard code.

SAP Useful References SAP Help Portal: eDocument solution for Mexico.

SAP Help-Mexico

SAP Community-Process Statuses for eDocuments in Mexico

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud ‚Äì Blog #1 in the Series
entry.content:
Organizations around the world are migrating their databases to the cloud, striving to increase operational efficiency, performance, and scalability while reducing costs. But not all databases are created equal.

SAP HANA Cloud is a cloud-native, in-memory database that delivers high performance, scalability, and powerful analytics. It lets you store, process, and query various types of data and models in a single system. Developers can build and deploy intelligent applications, rapidly and at scale. These are just a few of the reasons why so many companies have moved to SAP HANA Cloud.

The value is clear. In a recent study,[1]  IDC found that large enterprises could realize an annual average value of US$13.7 million by using SAP HANA Cloud. This benefit equates to $820,000 per SAP HANA Cloud database per year, with a three-year ROI of 352%. Isn‚Äôt that impressive?

The promise of SAP HANA Cloud is attractive for organizations considering a database migration. But you still need to make your business case to justify a modernization initiative.

To help you develop your argument, I‚Äôve created this blog series on the top 10 benefits of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud. In each blog, I‚Äôll review some of the key features and capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud and explore how each one can help your organization realize critical business value. Let‚Äôs get started.

Multi-model engines

No enterprise relies on only one type of data. Depending on your business, you may be using relational, geospatial, graph, JSON, and vector data, for example. This data can be structured, semi-structured, or unstructured, including text and multimedia content. Some organizations funnel data into single-purpose databases that handle only certain data types. But that database specialization creates additional costs, management effort, and complexity.

SAP HANA Cloud handles diverse workloads within a unified system‚Äîprocessing relational, geospatial, knowledge graph, time series, and vector data for AI applications. This ability to support multi-modal AI, where systems comprehend and process information from various data types, adds versatility. Application developers can integrate diverse data sources into a single application with ease and users can query and blend diverse data types intuitively. Multi-modal AI also reduces the need for complex ETL processes between systems.

The multi-model capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud deliver value by improving productivity. Developers can accelerate the development of AI-infused intelligent applications thanks to native support for predictive modeling, similarity searches, and graph analysis. By reducing the barriers to business data access and enabling faster, more informed decision-making, SAP HANA Cloud can speed up decision-making and improve overall business effectiveness.

Considering these benefits, IDC calculated that SAP HANA Cloud could enable overall productivity gains of 18%, creating an annual business value of $7.8 million. In the study, one entertainment industry executive summarized how the database delivered value for his company.

‚ÄúSAP HANA Cloud is a more modernized system that has resulted in time savings for developers, analytics, and administration because of the robust integrated tools provided, templates, and modelling capabilities,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSAP HANA Cloud has enabled my organization to make better business decisions and build better models, which drives business growth.‚Äù

Read more to build your business case

Multi-model engines are just one feature of SAP HANA Cloud that can accelerate your organization‚Äôs journey to modernization while reducing costs and maximizing efficiency. The following blogs in this series review additional capabilities that can help you build your business case while preparing for the future of modern, intelligent applications and processes.

Watch out the next blog, which discusses SAP HANA Cloud‚Äôs infrastructure independence and next-generation application foundation.

Additional resources:

What‚Äôs the potential value of SAP HANA Cloud for your organization? Complete this short assessment. 

Learn more about SAP HANA Cloud.

Discover how moving to SAP HANA Cloud helps you create a foundation for modernization.

Explore this guide on building a compelling business case to move your database to the cloud.

 

[1] . ‚ÄúThe Business Value of SAP HANA Cloud,‚Äù IDC, sponsored by SAP, April 2025.

entry.title: Enterprise Management Layer for SAP S/4HANA - New Release (OP2023 - SPS04) Announcement
entry.content:
Our enterprise management layer template based on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition OP2023 has been upgraded with some content released for SPS04 and will soon be available for customers to buy from SAP. We are aiming for mid-September 2025.

The new release does not include major scope item updates (addition, updates, obsolete), but provides an upgraded template with some OSS notes delivered by SPS04 being applied, essentially in the context of Localization. 

In the context of Localization, the following documents/scope items have been updated (new version):

  • EML_2023_DRC01_BPD_EN_XX_V1.3.1
  • EML_2023_LOC01_BPD_EN_XX_V1.3.1
  • EML_2023_LOC11_BPD_EN_EE_V1.3.1
  • EML_2023_LOC11_BPD_EN_IN_V1.3.1
  • EML_2023_LOC11_BPD_EN_PL_V1.3.1

Some further enhancements/updates are also provided:

  • Under Service Option VP01 - Intercompany Sales and Returns, it is now possible to create delivery related pro-forma Intercompany Invoices, see scope items ‚ÄúAdvanced Intercompany Sales (5D2)‚Äù and ‚ÄúAccelerated Returns to Central Stock with VSIT Replacement Delivery (IC31V)‚Äù.
  • Under Service Option VP02 - Cross-Plant Stock Transfer, we have added scope item SC23 Cross-Plant Stock Transfer with STO with EWM in both Plants and Exceptions. This scope item addresses how to deal with quantity shortages during put away, its clearance and follow up activities.
  • Under Service Option VP07 - Intercompany Billing of Services, we have added scope item SRV30 Intercompany Billing of Service Orders ‚Äì In House Repair. The scope items describes how an affiliate company supplies repair services on items returned from a customer to an ordering company. The supplying company records time on an intercompany service order as basis for Intercompany billing.  After repair, the ordering company send the repaired item back to the customer and creates a customer billing document for the repair services.

You can refer to our previous enterprise management layer template version based on FPS03, which contained the wider scope updates, here: Enterprise Management Layer for SAP S/4HANA - New ... - SAP Community.

entry.title: SAP Joule for consultant
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

As I‚Äôm working in SAP and closely with SAP clients, and more and more of them are asking questions about SAP Joule SAP‚Äôs smart digital assistant. I‚Äôd like to better support them, and I‚Äôm looking for advice or best practices from SAP Specialist who‚Äôve already helped clients get started with Joule.

To summarize what I‚Äôve gathered so far (and please correct me if I‚Äôm wrong):
‚Ä¢ SAP Joule is a digital assistant integrated into SAP systems. It can answer natural language questions, surface data quickly, and even guide users step by step through business processes.

‚Ä¢ To use Joule, clients need two things:
1. Access to the SAP Cloud (where Joule lives): usually available if they already use SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SuccessFactors, etc. If not, a new SAP BTP subaccount can be created.
2. A Joule license : this is the "key" to activate Joule. Without this, even if the cloud environment is ready, they can't access the assistant.

My main questions:
‚Ä¢ What are the exact steps for me to verify if a client already has access to Joule (license and technical setup)?
‚Ä¢ If they don‚Äôt, how do we guide them in activating Joule or requesting access?
‚Ä¢ Are there tools or standard SAP notes to help consultants evaluate a client‚Äôs readiness for Joule?

entry.title: From Paper to Pocket: How Mobile Transformed the Technician‚Äôs Day
entry.content:
From Paper to Pocket: How Mobile Transformed the Technician‚Äôs Day

(Blog 3 of the ‚ÄúTransformation in Field Service‚Äù series)

In my first blog on transformation in Field Service , I drew on the book Switch by Chip and Dan Heath, which describes the Elephant, the Rider, and the Path as a model for driving change. The Rider represents logic and rational arguments, the Elephant our emotions and habits, and the Path the environment that makes change easier or harder.

This framework is especially relevant when we look at how field service has transformed with mobile technology. Technicians didn‚Äôt choose their career because they love software. Quite the opposite: many wanted a job in the field, not behind a desk. Introducing mobile apps into their daily work often triggered skepticism, resistance, or even fear. But with the right balance of Rider, Elephant, and Path, mobile solutions have not only been adopted but have become indispensable.

Early lessons from the field

Looking back at my own career, I‚Äôve seen firsthand how difficult ‚Äî and rewarding ‚Äî mobile transformation can be.

  • 2010: Sales reps in medical technology
    We were rolling out a mobile app for sales representatives at a time when smartphones were still new. These reps were the true experts on their products ‚Äî often even more knowledgeable than the doctors they visited. The app provided critical customer relationship information, helping them navigate the complex networks of hospitals and physicians, while also capturing what was discussed or trained during visits.
    The Rider argument was clear: better information, fewer manual notes. The Elephant, however, feared that pulling out a phone during a delicate conversation with a doctor would hurt the personal relationship. It took careful guidance, success stories, and a clear Path (simple user interface, offline support) to convince them that mobile would strengthen, not weaken, their professional credibility.

  • 2012: German Workers Council and route optimization
    In Germany, we implemented a mobile solution that tracked technician movements to enable route optimization. At first, this raised strong concerns from the Workers Council about surveillance. Transparency, open discussions, and clear boundaries on data usage were essential. Once trust was established, the project gained approval, and the efficiency benefits were clear. This was an Elephant challenge ‚Äî overcoming emotional resistance by addressing fears directly and respectfully.
  • 2015: Agricultural device technicians
    Another challenge was rolling out a mobile solution to technicians servicing agricultural machinery in rural areas. Connectivity was often non-existent, and yet compliance required a full report with all parts used ‚Äî printed and handed directly to the farmer. A digital solution had to be offline-first, integrate seamlessly with backend systems, and still produce a paper record. It wasn‚Äôt glamorous, but it worked. Here, the Path was the key: designing the environment so the app could deliver value even without network coverage.

     

Field Reality Check ‚Äì Power Stations in Morocco

One of the most eye-opening experiences for me came while supporting a customer maintaining power stations. We sent developers and UX designers to join a major outage in Morocco to understand the daily challenges of technicians using our mobile solution.

What we learned was humbling: technicians didn‚Äôt complain much about the app itself ‚Äî they had bigger issues. Sometimes the right people didn‚Äôt show up on the outage day, so last-minute stand-ins had to be onboarded with a new user profile. Breaks had to be planned carefully because the nearest toilets were a kilometer away from the inspection area.

And yet, even with these very human, practical obstacles, technicians still valued the mobile solution. Why? Because they no longer had to drag cartons of paper folders with technical drawings around or try to scribble measurement results on dusty, wet paper. Having everything on a tablet ‚Äî documentation, tasks, forms ‚Äî made their work lighter, faster, and more accurate.

This experience was a powerful reminder: in transformation, context matters. The Elephant, Rider, and Path don‚Äôt exist in isolation. Mobile adoption wasn‚Äôt just about the app being user-friendly ‚Äî it was about reducing friction in a tough environment and giving technicians tools that fit into their real-world constraints.

Before & After: What Changed with Mobile

Transformation is most tangible when we look at the ‚Äúbefore‚Äù and ‚Äúafter.‚Äù Here are a few snapshots from my own journey and customer projects:

  • Med Tech Sales Reps

    • Before: Reps carried binders, scribbled notes after complex hospital and doctor visits, and often relied on memory to track conversations.

    • After: A mobile app provided structured customer data, captured discussion feedback instantly, and helped reps share insights across the team. Reps could focus on relationships ‚Äî not paperwork.

       

  • Field Service Route Optimization

    • Before: Dispatchers planned routes manually, and any attempt to track technician movements risked conflict with the German Workers Council.

    • After: With early buy-in from the council, a mobile-based routing solution was deployed. This reduced travel times, increased the number of jobs per day, and still respected employee privacy.

  • Agricultural Device Technicians

    • Before: At the end of a job, technicians had to manually write which parts were used when maintaining equipment. This was time-consuming and error-prone.

    • After: Mobile offline capability allowed them to get parts information and complete digital reports on-site, printing offline and automatically syncing once connected. Farmers received accurate documentation without delay.

  • Power Station Outages

    • Before: Cartons of paper, handwritten notes on dusty, wet surfaces, and heavy binders to carry across the site.

    • After: A tablet with everything in one place ‚Äî tasks, history, and reporting ‚Äî freeing technicians to focus on the real challenges of the outage.

       

Real-World Proof Points

Across industries, the results of mobile transformation in field service are clear:

  • First-time-fix rates improved as technicians gained instant access to AI-driven equipment insights and past resolutions.

  • Route optimization reduced travel times significantly, freeing up more hours for actual service.

  • Mobile apps with dynamic forms ensured compliance and accuracy, even offline.

  • Technicians reported higher job satisfaction when technology took away tedious reporting tasks, letting them shine in front of customers.

The rain boots moment

For me, this journey always brings to mind a familiar scene with my children: getting them to put on their rain boots before going outside. In the moment, they resist ‚Äî because they‚Äôre busy running around in socks or tumbling across the gym floor.  But once they‚Äôre outside, jumping happily in puddles, they wouldn‚Äôt want to be without those boots.

Technicians often react the same way when first introduced to mobile apps. They resist because it feels like a distraction from the ‚Äúreal work.‚Äù But once they‚Äôre out in the field ‚Äî fixing equipment faster, looking professional in front of customers, and avoiding paperwork ‚Äî they realize the tools make their job better.

Mobile transformation in field service is about more than technology. It‚Äôs about balancing logic, emotion, and environment ‚Äî and showing people that the rain boots make the experience not just easier, but more enjoyable.

entry.title: Re: Batch Inbound Integration - Use of element ChangeOrdi...
entry.content:
Hello @robert_siebert 

Your understanding of the ChangeOrdinalNumberValue element is accurate. This value plays a crucial role in the Batch Inbound Integration SOAP API, acting as a version control to ensure data integrity and prevent updates from being overlooked or processed in the wrong order.

Reasons to Avoid Using a Timestamp

Using a timestamp is unreliable because of potential issues with clock synchronisation and the risk of concurrent updates generating identical timestamps. The ChangeOrdinalNumberValue is a SAP-generated value that guarantees a strict sequential order.

The Best Practice

The most reliable and recommended approach is for your third-party WMS to store the ChangeOrdinalNumberValue from SAP's response.

Initial Creation: When the WMS creates a new batch in SAP, it must record and store the ChangeOrdinalNumberValue returned in SAP's successful response.

For all future updates to the same batch, the WMS must include the most recent ChangeOrdinalNumberValue in its request to SAP.

This guarantees that each update is applied to the correct version of the batch record, avoiding data inconsistencies and complying with the API's design for dependable integration.

References

  • SAP API Business Hub: The official documentation for the Batch Inbound Integration API explains the payload structure and the purpose of the ChangeOrdinalNumberValue field. You can find this documentation at Business Accelerator Hub
  • SAP Help Portal: The SAP Help Portal's documentation on batch management and integration offers a broader overview of managing master data updates. You can access this documentation at Batch - Inbound Integration.

This video provides an introduction to SAP Business Hub, an essential tool for exploring and testing SAP APIs. How to Search for SAP Standard API - Introduction to SAP Business Hub

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Enhance ECC Extractor via CMOD on virtual provider ba...
entry.content:
Hi Shlomi

The F1 help for direct access shows the following information:

Load Without PSA (By Direct Access)

If you select this setting, data is not extracted from the Persistent Staging Area (PSA) of the DataSource. Instead the data is requested directly from the data source at the runtime of the DTP.

Use

You can load the data for all source systems without PSA directly into the InfoProvider, if you extract small quantities of data using a DTP with the 'Full' extraction mode (for example, small quantities of master data).

For ODP source systems you can also load mass data and delta directly into the InfoProvider.

Dependencies

You need not create an InfoPackage in order to extract data from the source.

Note that the file is available on the server when you are extracting from a file source system.

For all source systems apart from the ODP source system, the data source is accessed in "direct access mode". This has certain implications, especially when extracting from SAPI systems:

  • The data is extracted synchronously. This places special requirements on main memory, especially in the remote system.
  • The SAPI extractors might behave differently than for asynchronous loading since they are informed by the direct access.
  • No SAPI customer enhancements are processed. Fields that were added to the DataSource with append technology are left empty. Exits RSAP0001, exit_saplrsap_001, exit_saplrsap_002 and exit_saplrsap_004 are not executed.
  • If errors occur during processing, you need to extract the data again in BW because the PSA is not available in the buffer. This means that it is not possible to create a delta.
  • The filter in the DTP only contains fields that are allowed as selection fields by the DataSource. If a PSA is available, you can use all the fields for filtering in the DTP.

 

br

Roland

entry.title: Re: Issue with Capacity Category 001 in Scope Item 31L
entry.content:
Hello @sergio21 

Thank you for your question. Please note that in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Starter System, your observed behaviour is expected.

  • Capacity Category 001 (Machine) and its associated values such as start time, end time, break length, utilization, etc. are delivered as preconfigured reference content and are locked in the starter system. These entries cannot be modified because the Starter System is meant for exploration and demo purposes, not for customizing the underlying standard configuration.
  • The error message you received reflects the restriction in the Starter System.

In your Quality or Productive system, you can configure work center capacities through SSCUI 102402 Define Work Center Capacity or via the Manage Work Center Capacity app. Doing this will allow you to maintain shift intervals, capacity utilization, and individual capacity values as per your business requirement.

To summarize, Starter System restriction‚Äôs values are locked and cannot be edited. Quality/Production system configuration is open via SSCUIs and apps. You will be able to maintain and adapt the capacity categories, intervals and standard available capacities.

For more details refer to the following link.

Manage Work Center Capacity

I hope this provides the desired insights. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris
